Bending Angle of a Bimetallic Strip

statement.p: A bimetallic strip of length 8 cm and thickness 1 mm at 25^{\circ}C made of brass and steel is to be used for measuring the temperature. When the bimetal strip is placed in 200^{\circ}C superheated steam, the strip bends such that the strip makes an arc of angle theta as shown in . Find this angle.

hint.p: Work out the change in lengths of the two metals.

sidebyside.p: Let s_1 and s_2 be the lengths of the two metal strips separated by thickness w, which we will assume to be same after heating as before. Let r_1 and r_2 be the radii of the arcs of the two metals. Here we use the subscript 1 for the metal that expands less and hence is inside part of the arc.

solution.p:
From the thermal expansion from the original length h we have
\amp s_1 - h = \alpha_1 h \Delta T, \amp s_2 - h = \alpha_2 h \Delta T.
From the geometry we have
\amp s_1= r_1 \theta, \amp s_2 = r_2 \theta.
Combining the two and using r_2-r_1 = w we get
\theta = \frac{h}{w} \left(\alpha_2 - \alpha_1 \right) \Delta T.
Now, putting in the numbers we find
\theta \amp = \frac{8\ \text{cm}}{0.1\ \text{cm}}\times \frac{ \left(20.3 - 11.7 \right)\times 10^{-6}}{\ ^{\circ}\text{C}}\times 175^{\circ}\text{C}, \amp = 0.12\ \text{rad} = 6.9^{\circ}.

problem.title: Problem with Using Platinium-Iridium Rod for Meter

statement.p: One of the major problems with a standard of length based on a physical material such as a platinum rod is the expansion of the rod with the temperature.

We are supposed to compare other rods with the standard platinum-iridium rod which is assumed to be of a fixed length of 1 m. If the standard rod is 1 m at 20^{\circ}\text{C}, what will be the error in assuming the the rod is still 1 m at 27^{\circ}\text{C}?

solution.p:
The absolute error will be the unaccounted-for extra length due to the thermal expansion.
\Delta L \amp= \alpha L \Delta T, \amp = \frac{8.7\times 10^{-6}}{\ ^{\circ}\text{C}}\times 1\ \text{m} \times 7^{\circ}\text{C} = 61\ \mu\textrm{m}.
Percentage error will be
\dfrac{\Delta L}{L} = 61\times 10^{-6} = 0.0061\%.

problem.title: (Calculus) Slowing of Pendulum with Rise in Temperature

statement.p:
The frequency of a pendulum in a grandfather clock made of brass is related to its length L and acceleration due to gravity g of earth by the following equation.
f = \frac{1}{2\pi}\sqrt{\frac{g}{L}}
The clock is calibrated to give the accurate time when the temperature is 20^{\circ}\text{C}. How much will the clock be off in an 8 hour period when the temperature is 30^{\circ}\text{C}?

solution.p:
At higher temperarture, L be larger, and hence f smaller. Let \Delta L be the increase in length.
\dfrac{\Delta L}{L} = \alpha \Delta T.
Let \Delta f be the change in frequency due to a chenge \Delta L in length. From the frequency formula we will get
\Delta f \amp = \dfrac{df}{dL} \Delta L, \amp = -\frac{\sqrt{g}}{2\pi} \frac{1}{2L\sqrt{L}} \Delta L, \amp = -\frac{f}{2L}\Delta L, \amp = -\frac{1}{2}\, f\, \dfrac{\Delta L}{L},
Therefore,
\Delta f = -\dfrac{1}{2}\, f\, \alpha \Delta T.
Putting in the given numbers we obtain
\left| \frac{\Delta f}{f} \right| \amp = \frac{1}{2}\times \frac{20.3\times 10^{-6}}{\ ^{\circ}\text{C}}\times 10^{\circ}\text{C} \amp = 1.015\times 10^{-6}.
Since f=1/\tau, where \tau is the period, the relative change in the period will be related to the relative change in frequency by
\left|\frac{\Delta\tau}{\tau}\right| = \left|\frac{\Delta f}{f}\right| = 1.015\times 10^{-6}.
Since f will decrease, the time \tau will increase. That is, the clock will run slower. Therefore the time difference over a time period of 8\text{ h} will be
|\Delta \tau| = 1.015\times 10^{-6}\times 8\times 3600\ \text{s}= 0.03\ \text{s}.
